details.title: An examination of correlation effects among warranty claims

authors.affiliation: Gen. Motors R&D Center, Warren, MI, USA

p: Debra A. Elkins is a Senior Research Engineer at General Motors R&D Center in Warren, Michigan. She received her B.S. in Mathematical Physics (1993) from Sweet Briar College in Virginia, M.S. in Mathematics (1995) and Ph.D. in Industrial Engineering (2000) from Texas A&M University. Her research interests include computational probability, risk analysis, and the decision sciences.

authors.name: D.A. Elkins

p: Martin A. Wortman is a Professor of Industrial Engineering at Texas A&M University. His research interests lie within applied probability, stochastic processes, and queueing theory.

details.abstract: This paper models & examines the impact of correlation in a failure arrival process which generates a warranty claim with each occurring failure. We show that even slight positive correlation in the warranty claims arrival process can significantly impact the expected number of claims observed, and the length of the transient period. We are not suggesting that renewal processes are necessarily inappropriate or incorrect as models for the arriving warranty claims process. Rather, we emphasize the importance of considering correlation in the claims arrival process, and suggest that more research is needed to explore mathematical models which explicitly consider correlation in the warranty analysis framework.

references.title: The Effects of the Dependency in the Markov Renewal Arrival Process on the Various Performance Measures of Exponential Server Queues

context.text: Patuwo [1], and Patuwo, Disney, & McNickle [2] consider a MR/M/1 queue (a queue with a MRAP and exponentially distributed service times) to study the impact of correlation on mean queue length.

references.text: B. Patuwo, The Effects of the Dependency in the Markov Renewal Arrival Process on the Various Performance Measures of Exponential Server Queues, 1989.

references.title: The effect of correlated arrivals on queues

context.text: Patuwo [1], and Patuwo, Disney, & McNickle [2] consider a MR/M/1 queue (a queue with a MRAP and exponentially distributed service times) to study the impact of correlation on mean queue length.

references.text: B. Patuwo, R. Disney, D. McNickle, "The effect of correlated arrivals on queues", IIE Transactions, vol. 25, pp. 105-110, 1993.

references.title: The Effect of Positively Correlated Arrivals on the Single Server Queue

context.text: Hur [3] explores positively correlated arrivals for a single server queue, and develops analytical results to measure the effect of correlation on queueing behavior.

To study the influence of correlation in the claims arrival process, we employ a MRAP introduced by Hur [3], to vary the dependency among arrivals while maintaining identically distributed inter-arrival times.

Hur [3] proves that this MRAP is positively correlated when \${(1/N)} < p \le 1\$, and shows that the lag-\$r\$ correlation coefficient is given by  where (\$\mu _{i}\$, \$\sigma _{i}^{2}\$) are the mean and variance of distribution \$G(i,t)\$.

references.text: S. Hur, The Effect of Positively Correlated Arrivals on the Single Server Queue, 1993.

references.title: The impact of autocorrelation on queueing systems

context.text: Livny, Melamed, & Tsiolis [4] report on a simulation study of queues with correlated arrival or service processes, examining queueing behavior as a function of dependency parameters (correlation coefficients of the arrival and service processes, and traffic intensities).

references.text: M. Livny, B. Melamed, A. Tsiolis, "The impact of autocorrelation on queueing systems", Management Science, vol. 39, pp. 322-339, 1993.

references.title: Statistical techniques for warranty cost analysis

context.text: We are aware of no prior work in warranty modeling which considers correlation among claims; however, renewal process models appear widely in the warranty literature [5]–[13].

references.text: W. Blischke, D. Murthy, "Statistical techniques for warranty cost analysis" in Product Warranty Handbook, pp. 191-230, 1996, Marcel Dekker.

Warranty analysis literature focuses primarily on cost analysis & different warranty policies, such as free replacement, pro rata rebates, and various combination warranties [6], [14]–[20].

references.text: W. Blischke, D. Murthy, Warranty Cost Analysis, 1993, Marcel Dekker.

references.title: Cost analysis of two-attribute warranty policies based on the product usage rate

context.text: Warranty analysis literature focuses primarily on cost analysis & different warranty policies, such as free replacement, pro rata rebates, and various combination warranties [6], [14]–[15][20].

links.abstract: In the so-called two-attribute warranty policy, two types of warranty criteria, such as the age and mileage of an automobile, are employed simultaneously to determine the eligibility of a warranty claim. The authors propose in the paper several decision models that estimate the expected total cost incurred under various types of two-attribute warranty policies. They also perform a sensitivity analysis to study the effects of several model parameters, such as the discount rate, the product usage ...

references.text: Y. H. Chun, K. Tang, "Cost analysis of two-attribute warranty policies based on the product usage rate", IEEE Transactions on Engineering Management, vol. 46, pp. 201-209, 1999.

references.title: Warranty cost&#821Risk analysis

context.text: Warranty analysis literature focuses primarily on cost analysis & different warranty policies, such as free replacement, pro rata rebates, and various combination warranties [6], [14]–[16][20].

links.abstract: An approach to quantify the risk associated with a warranty price is presented. This method, based on Monte Carlo simulation, can give management an analytical assessment of the risk involved, thus permitting a more informed decision. Managers can visually trade off warranty cost and risk to maintain a balance between competitive pressures and acceptable risk. Other methods for warranty pricing based on a point estimate or a percent of production cost will not provide a quantitative valuation of...

references.text: D. N. Isaacson, S. Reid, J. R. Brennan, "Warranty cost̵Risk analysis", Annual Proceedings of the Reliability and Maintainability Symposium, pp. 332-339, 1991.

references.title: A nonrenewable minimal-repair warranty policy with time-dependent costs

context.text: Warranty analysis literature focuses primarily on cost analysis & different warranty policies, such as free replacement, pro rata rebates, and various combination warranties [6], [14]–[17][20].

links.abstract: Estimating warranty costs during the life cycle of a product is important to the manufacturer, who has to plan for creating a fund for warranty reserves. Replacement or repair costs associated with product-failure within the warranty period are drawn from this fund. This paper considers a policy where warranty is not renewed on product failure within the warranty period but the product is minimally repaired by the manufacturer. This implies that, on repair, the failure rate of the item remains t...

references.text: S.-S. Ja, V. G. Kulkarni, A. Mitra, J. G. Patankar, "A nonrenewable minimal-repair warranty policy with time-dependent costs", IEEE Transactions on Reliability, vol. 50, pp. 346-352, 2001.

references.title: G-renewal process as a model for statistical warranty claim prediction

context.text: Warranty analysis literature focuses primarily on cost analysis & different warranty policies, such as free replacement, pro rata rebates, and various combination warranties [6], [14]–[18][20].

links.abstract: A brief overview of the statistical aspects of warranty prediction is given as an introduction. The main discussion then focuses on warranty claim prediction for repairable products. Introduced by Kijima and Sumita (1986), a g-renewal process (GRP) can be considered as a model for major repair assumptions encountered in repairable product reliability analysis. These assumptions include "good-as-new", "same-as-old", the intermediate "better-than-old-but-worse-than-new", and "worse-than-old". A st...

references.text: M. P. Kaminskiy, V. V. Krivtsov, "G-renewal process as a model for statistical warranty claim prediction", Annual Proceedings of the Reliability and Maintainability Symposium, pp. 276-280, 2000.

references.title: An integrated multicriteria model for warranty cost estimation and production

context.text: Warranty analysis literature focuses primarily on cost analysis & different warranty policies, such as free replacement, pro rata rebates, and various combination warranties [6], [14]–[19][20].

links.abstract: Warranty cost estimation for multiple products is considered. The decision variables include the price, warranty time, production quantity, and lot size. System constraints on the above decision variables are based on absolute minimum and maximum values between which those variables should lie. Several goals are considered at different levels of priorities. Some of these goals may be conflicting. The goals considered included operation within a limited resource capacity, the achievement of a spe...

references.text: A. Mitra, J. G. Patankar, "An integrated multicriteria model for warranty cost estimation and production", IIE Transactions on Engineering Management, vol. 40, no. 3, pp. 300-311, 1993.

references.title: Warranty cost estimation using simulation

context.text: Warranty analysis literature focuses primarily on cost analysis & different warranty policies, such as free replacement, pro rata rebates, and various combination warranties [6], [14]–[20].

links.abstract: The purpose of this paper is to consider a warranty estimation problem using a simulation approach. Prior research has estimated warranty costs using mathematical expectations. In the simulated approach, the time to failure has been assumed to be exponentially distributed. Three different rebate functions are considered: a linear pro rata rebate, a lump-sum rebate, and a full rebate up to a certain point and a linear pro rata from then until the warranty expires.

references.text: J. G. Patankar, K. A. Klafehn, "Warranty cost estimation using simulation", Proceedings of the 1988 Winter Simulation Conference, pp. 857-859, 1988.

references.title: Bibliography on warranties

context.text: [21]provide an extensive list of articles, reports, books, and theses discussing the different aspects of warranty including legal issues, marketing & consumer behavior, basic types of coverage policies, financial accounting, and public perception.

references.text: W. Blischke, D. Murthy, "Bibliography on warranties" in Product Warranty Handbook, pp. 839-916, 1996, Marcel Dekker.

references.title: A Fast Parallel Algorithm to Numerically Compute the Markov Renewal Kernel via Tight Lower and Upper Bounds

context.text: Recent progress in computational probability now provides a means to compute certain Markov renewal kernels numerically [23], [24], which can be used to compute the expected number of MRAP claim arrivals in \$(0,t]\$.
The Markov renewal kernel is generally not available in closed form, but may be obtained numerically [23], [24].
The renewal function \${\mathtilde {M}}(t)\$, and the Markov renewal kernel \$R(t)\$ are computed numerically using an algorithm developed by Elkins [23], [24].

references.text: D. Elkins, A Fast Parallel Algorithm to Numerically Compute the Markov Renewal Kernel via Tight Lower and Upper Bounds, 2000.

references.title: On numerical solution of the Markov renewal equation: Tight upper and lower kernel bounds

context.text: Recent progress in computational probability now provides a means to compute certain Markov renewal kernels numerically [23], [24], which can be used to compute the expected number of MRAP claim arrivals in \$(0,t]\$.
The Markov renewal kernel is generally not available in closed form, but may be obtained numerically [23], [24].
The renewal function \${\mathtilde {M}}(t)\$, and the Markov renewal kernel \$R(t)\$ are computed numerically using an algorithm developed by Elkins [23], [24].

references.text: D. Elkins, M. Wortman, "On numerical solution of the Markov renewal equation: Tight upper and lower kernel bounds", Methodology and Computing in Applied Probability, vol. 3, no. 3, pp. 239-253, 2001.

references.title: Introduction to Stochastic Processes

context.text: Consider a Markov Renewal Arrival Process (MRAP) using the notation & terminology of Çinlar [25].
A Markov Chain whose transition matrix is doubly stochastic has a uniform stationary distribution when the state space \$E\$ is finite [25].

Appealing to the elementary renewal theorem [25], the expected (limiting) arrival rate for the renewal process is  Similarly, the expected (limiting) arrival rate for the MRAP is given by  where \$N_{t}^{j}\$ is the expected number of claim arrivals of type \$j\$ in \$(0,t]\$, \$\gamma _{i} = \Pr\{X_{0} = i\}\$, and \$R(i,j,t)\$ is the \$(i,j)\$th element of the Markov renewal kernel.

references.text: E.Çinlar, Introduction to Stochastic Processes, 1975, Prentice-Hall.

references.title: Traffic Processes in Queueing Networks: A Markov Renewal Approach

references.text: R. Disney, P. Kiessler, Traffic Processes in Queueing Networks: A Markov Renewal Approach, 1987, The Johns Hopkins University Press.

references.title: Markov renewal processes and renewal processes: Some conditions on equivalence

context.text: For results on the equivalence between renewal and Markov renewal processes, the interested reader should refer to Simon & Disney [27].
